awd_titl_txt: Designing Biomimetic Robots:  Researching the impact of an interdisciplinary bio-engineering-computational design curriculum on middle school engineering and science education
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is funded by the STEM+Computing program, which seeks to advance applied research on the integration of computational thinking and computing activities within the disciplines of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). In most middle schools, learning is segregated by discipline - science is taught in one class, and engineering or computing are taught in another, if at all.  Yet today discovery and innovation are interdisciplinary and students need to use skills and practices from multiple subject areas to solve problems.  The Designing Biomimetic Robots project will develop and study an education program that integrates science, engineering, and computing by engaging students in biomimicry design challenges to support students in developing computational thinking and scientific reasoning, as well as engineering design practices, while practicing interdisciplinary problem solving skills. Students will study the natural world to learn how animals and plants accomplish different tasks and then engineer a robot that is inspired by what they learned.  For example, they may use what they learn about how different animals pick up objects to design a robot that can assist wheelchair-bound people in picking up dropped items.  In addition, the project will demonstrate how teachers can foster interdisciplinary learning, and can broaden participation in science, engineering and computing among middle school students in diverse settings.

The project will develop an innovative intervention to support the development of interdisciplinary STEM knowledge and practices through a series of biomimetic design challenges.  The program will include: a) a 4-week modular and flexible curriculum that integrates bio-inspired engineering design, robotics, and computer programming content and practices into middle school STEM classrooms, b) a teacher professional development program, and c) web resources to support integration of biomimetic robotics into middle schools.  The goal is for all participating students to develop knowledge, practices, and skills consistent with engineering and science standards, and computational thinking principles, and demonstrate an understanding that computing enhances STEM practice and knowledge development.  Participating teachers will learn how to enact interdisciplinary instruction through integrating STEM and computing, and how to create task structures and discursive practices that support the participation of all students.  The project will contribute to theory about interdisciplinary and participatory learning environments that can foster students' learning about the intersections of computation, engineering, and biomimicry. The project will work with 24 middle school teachers and approximately 3,200 students in urban, suburban, and rural districts in Massachusetts, Maryland, and Maine that have diverse student demographics.

por.por_cntn:
STEM subjects are typically taught separately in middle schools yet are integrated in the STEM work world. Therefore, the education community has called for more research about how to design for and support integrated learning. The Designing Biomimetic Robots (BioRobots) curriculum (https://www.terc.edu/biorobots) uses biomimetic robot design as a natural context to integrate science, engineering, and computational thinking. During 21 class sessions, students research the relationship between digging structures and how they function in four different kinds of digging animals, and then design, build, and program a prototype search-and-rescue robot that can dig through rubble (shredded paper). 

Over three years, the project worked with 21 science, engineering, and technology teachers and over 800 6th - 8th grade students in urban and suburban schools across three states.   We redesigned the curriculum several times to narrow the focus of the design task, balance the primary disciplines involved, and support teachers and students to engage in interdisciplinary reasoning. The final version provided teachers and students with clear instructional supports for students to reason across disciplines and to strengthen uptake of computational thinking, biology, and engineering practices.

Student Learning.    During the curriculum, students created sketches, storyboards, physical prototypes and Scratch/MakeCode programs; they drew links among these representations to understand the central concept of structure-function relationships. For example, after (a) decomposing the digging structures of a mole (an animal well-adapted for digging) by breaking down the stages in its digging movements and creating a poster, (b) developing gestures, for example, swimming motions with their hands, that represent the mole?s movement abstractly, and (c) building elements of an early robot prototype, students coordinated these representations. They were thus able to see connections between the structures and functions of the animal and of the robot. These structure-function connections helped the group enact their design.

An analysis of 61 robots from years one and two of the project showed a wide diversity of robot designs as students incorporated their understanding of animal structure and function. A case study from a year two 7th grade engineering classroom showed how students built understanding by traversing back-and-forth between the disciplines throughout.  Assessments from 182 students in year three showed growth in their skill in applying computational thinking (decomposition, abstraction, algorithmic thinking) both in biology and in engineering. 

Teacher Implementation.    Teachers in all districts have been challenged by the new standards for middle school, which encourage integration of science, engineering, and computing skills.  Teachers participating in the BioRobots project have directly benefited by deepening their understanding of how to integrate a wide range of STEM practices.  BioRobots teachers found the curriculum interesting, adaptable, and highly engaging for their students.

There were challenges in designing for teachers with different disciplinary backgrounds. However, we found that the teachers felt supported to implement practices outside of their discipline, to highlight connections to their primary discipline and, in some cases, to use the materials to anchor discipline-relevant themes throughout the year, not only when implementing the curriculum. Informally, participating teachers have expressed enthusiasm and plans for continuing to use BioRobots (in whole or in part) with future cohorts of students.

Impacts.     This project offers an alternative to the many existing middle school activities that introduce robotic technology by focusing on wheeled robots, robot competitions, and expensive robot construction kits. BioRobots uses an affordable robotics kit (the Hummingbird:bit), combined with science ideas and practices, to engage a wide range of students in collaborative robot design. The collaborative and science-aligned features of the curriculum may have supported its ability to engage a wider range of students than those who would typically self-select into an extracurricular robotics program. 

Finally, a high-level impact of the BioRobots project is a proof-of-concept that it is possible within one single curriculum unit - if cohesively designed around an authentic design task and infused with the biomimetic design approach - for middle school students to make progress toward learning goals in life science, engineering design, and computational thinking. In fact, the integration of multiple STEM domains supports learning within each individual domain. This result should motivate new work on middle school curricula that addresses multiple STEM domains within a single overarching design task. Furthermore, the following curriculum design principles, emerging from this project, can impact future development efforts of interdisciplinary curricula:

  • Frequent student-created representations of natural phenomena AND designed systems 
  • A consistent concept, such as structure-function relationships, leveraged to analyze both natural phenomena and designed systems 
  • A carefully conceived design task whose solution can be meaningfully informed by both core science ideas and computational thinking practices 
  • Intentional decisions about the complexity and scope of physical materials and software used for building and programming.
